allow_deletion.description: `allow_deletion` determines whether users can delete their accounts.

allow_signup.description: `allow_signup` determines whether users are able to create new accounts.

mask.description:
`mask` determines whether sensitive information (usernames, emails) should be masked in the audit log output.

This configuration applies to logs written to the console as well as persisted logs.

enabled.description: `enabled` controls whether audit log output on the console is enabled or disabled.

output.description: `output` determines the output stream audit logs are sent to.

enabled.description: `enabled` controls whether audit log should be retained (i.e. persisted).

account.title: account
account.description: `account` configures settings related to user accounts.

audit_log.title: audit_log
audit_log.description: `audit_log` configures output and storage modalities of audit logs.

convert_legacy_config.description:
`convert_legacy_config`, if set to `true`, automatically copies the set values of deprecated configuration
options, to new ones. If set to `false`, these values have to be set manually if non-default values should be
used.

debug.description: `debug`, if set to `true`, adds additional debugging information to flow API responses.

email.title: email
email.description: `email` configures how email addresses of user accounts are acquired and used.

email_delivery.title: email_delivery
email_delivery.description: `email_delivery` configures how outgoing mails are delivered.

emails.title: emails
emails.description: Deprecated. See child properties for suggested replacements.

passcode.title: passcode
passcode.description: Deprecated. See child properties for suggested replacements.

passkey.title: passkey
passkey.description: `passkey` configures how passkeys  are acquired and used.

password.title: password
password.description: `password` configures how passwords are acquired and used.

rate_limiter.title: rate_limiter
rate_limiter.description: `rate_limiter` configures rate limits for rate limited API operations and storage modalities for rate limit data.

saml.title: saml
saml.description:
`saml` configures modalities of SAML (Security Assertion Markup Language) SSO authentication and SAML identity
providers.

secrets.title: secrets
secrets.description: `secrets` configures the keys used for cryptographically signing tokens issued by the API.

server.title: server
server.description: `server` configures address and CORS settings of the public and admin API.

session.title: session
session.description: `session` configures settings for session JWTs and Cookies issued by the API.

third_party.title: third_party
third_party.description:
`third_party` configures the modalities of third party OAuth/OIDC based authentication and available identity
providers.

username.title: username
username.description: `username` configures how usernames of user accounts are acquired and used.

webauthn.title: webauthn
webauthn.description: `webauthn` configures general settings for communication with the WebAuthentication API.

webhooks.title: webhooks
webhooks.description: `webhooks` configures HTTP-based callbacks for specific events occurring in the system.

Config.description: Config is the central configuration type

domain.description:
`domain` is the domain the cookie will be bound to. Works for subdomains, but not cross-domain.
See the `session.enable_auth_token_header` configuration instead if the API and the client application run on
different domains.

http_only.description: `http_only` determines whether cookies are HTTP only or accessible by Javascript.

name.description: `name` is the name of the cookie.

same_site.description:
`same_site` controls whether a cookie is sent with cross-site requests.
See [here](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/HTTP/Headers/Set-Cookie#samesitesamesite-value) for
more details.

secure.description:
`secure` indicates whether the cookie is sent to the server only when a request is made with the https: scheme
(except on localhost).

NOTE: `secure` must be set to `false` when working on `localhost` and with the Safari browser because it does
not store secure cookies on `localhost`.

allow_origins.title: allow_origins
allow_origins.description:
`allow_origins` determines the value of the Access-Control-Allow-Origin
response header. This header defines a list of [origins](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Glossary/Origin)
that may access the resource.

The wildcard characters `*` and `?` are supported and are converted to regex fragments `.*` and `.` accordingly.

unsafe_wildcard_origin_allowed.title: unsafe_wildcard_origin_allowed
unsafe_wildcard_origin_allowed.description:
`unsafe_wildcard_origin_allowed` allows a wildcard `*` origin to be used with AllowCredentials
flag. In that case we consider any origin allowed and send it back to the client in an `Access-Control-Allow-Origin` header.

This is INSECURE and potentially leads to [cross-origin](https://portswigger.net/research/exploiting-cors-misconfigurations-for-bitcoins-and-bounties)
attacks. See also https://github.com/labstack/echo/issues/2400 for discussion on the subject.

Optional. Default value is `false`.

database.description: `database` determines the name of the database schema to use.

dialect.description: `dialect` is the name of the database system to use.

host.description: `host` is the host the database system is running on.

password.description: `password` is the password for the database user to use for connecting to the database.

port.description: `port` is the port the database system is running on.

url.description:
`url` is a datasource connection string. It can be used instead of the rest of the database configuration
options. If this `url` is set then it is prioritized, i.e. the rest of the options, if set, have no effect.

Schema: `dialect://username:password@host:port/database`

user.description: `user` is the database user to use for connecting to the database.

acquire_on_login.description:
`acquire_on_login` determines whether users, provided that they do not already have registered an email,
	are prompted to provide an email on login.

acquire_on_registration.description: `acquire_on_registration` determines whether users are prompted to provide an email on registration.

limit.description: 'limit' determines the maximum number of emails a user can register.

max_length.description: `max_length` specifies the maximum allowed length of an email address.

optional.description:
`optional` determines whether users must provide an email when prompted.
There must always be at least one email address associated with an account. The primary email address cannot be
deleted if emails are required (`optional`: false`).

passcode_ttl.description: `passcode_ttl` specifies, in seconds, how long a passcode is valid for.

require_verification.description:
`require_verification` determines whether newly created emails must be verified by providing a passcode sent
to respective address.

use_as_login_identifier.description: `use_as_login_identifier` determines whether emails can be used as an identifier on login.

use_for_authentication.description:
`user_for_authentication` determines whether users can log in by providing an email address and subsequently
providing a passcode sent to the given email address.

enabled.description:
`enabled` determines whether the API delivers emails.
Disable if you want to send the emails yourself. To do so you must subscribe to the `email.create` webhook event.

from_address.description: `from_address` configures the sender address of emails sent to users.

from_name.description: `from_name` configures the sender name of emails sent to users.

smtp.title: smtp
smtp.description: `SMTP` contains the SMTP server settings for sending mails.

log_health_and_metrics.description: `log_health_and_metrics` determines whether requests of the `/health` and `/metrics` endpoints are logged.

email.description: Deprecated. See child properties for suggested replacements.

acquire_on_registration.description: `acquire_on_registration` configures how users are prompted creating a passkey on registration.

meta:enum.always: Indicates that users are always prompted to create a passkey on registration.
meta:enum.conditional:
Indicates that users are prompted to create a passkey on registration as long as the user does
						not have a password.

						If passwords are also conditionally acquired on registration, then users are given a choice as
						to what type of credential to create.
meta:enum.never: Indicates that users are never prompted to create a passkey on registration.

acquire_on_login.description: `acquire_on_login` configures how users are prompted creating a passkey on login.

meta:enum.always:
Indicates that users are always prompted to create a passkey on login
					provided that they do not already have a passkey.
meta:enum.conditional:
Indicates that users are prompted to create a passkey on login provided that
						they do not already have a passkey and do not have a password.

						If passkeys are also conditionally acquired on login then users are given a choice as to what
						type of credential to register.
meta:enum.never: Indicates that users are never prompted to create a passkey on login.

attestation_preference.description:
`attestation_preference` is used to specify the preference regarding attestation conveyance during
credential generation.

meta:enum.direct:
Indicates that the Relying Party wants to receive the attestation statement as generated by
					the authenticator.
meta:enum.indirect:
Indicates that the Relying Party prefers an attestation conveyance yielding verifiable
					attestation statements, but allows the client to decide how to obtain such attestation statements.
meta:enum.none: Indicates that the Relying Party is not interested in authenticator attestation.

enabled.description: `enabled` determines whether users can create or authenticate with passkeys.

limit.description: `limit` defines the maximum number of passkeys a user can have.

optional.description:
`optional` determines whether users must create a passkey when prompted. The last remaining passkey cannot be
deleted if passkeys are required (`optional: false`).

It also takes part in determining the order of password and passkey acquisition
on login and registration (see also `acquire_on_login` and `acquire_on_registration`): if one credential type is
required (`optional: false`) then that one takes precedence, i.e. is acquired first.

user_verification.description:
`user_verification` specifies the requirements regarding local authorization with an authenticator through
 various authorization gesture modalities; for example, through a touch plus pin code,
 password entry, or biometric recognition.

The setting applies to both WebAuthn registration and authentication ceremonies.

meta:enum.discouraged: Indicates that no user verification should be performed.
meta:enum.preferred:
Indicates that user verification is preferred but will not fail the operation if no
						user verification was performed.
meta:enum.required: Indicates that user verification is always required.

acquire_on_registration.description: `acquire_on_registration` configures how users are prompted creating a password on registration.

meta:enum.always: Indicates that users are always prompted to create a password on registration.
meta:enum.conditional:
Indicates that users are prompted to create a password on registration as long as the user does
						not have a passkey.

						If passkeys are also conditionally acquired on registration, then users are given a choice as
						to what type of credential to register.
meta:enum.never: Indicates that users are never prompted to create a password on registration.

acquire_on_login.description: `acquire_on_login` configures how users are prompted creating a password on login.

meta:enum.always:
Indicates that users are always prompted to create a password on login
					provided that they do not already have a password.
meta:enum.conditional:
Indicates that users are prompted to create a password on login provided that
						they do not already have a password and do not have a passkey.

						If passkeys are also conditionally acquired on login then users are given a choice as to what
						type of credential to register.
meta:enum.never: Indicates that users are never prompted to create a password on login.

enabled.description: `enabled` determines whether passwords are enabled or disabled.

optional.description:
`optional` determines whether users must set a password when prompted. The password cannot be deleted if
passwords are required (`optional: false`).

It also takes part in determining the order of password and passkey acquisition
on login and registration (see also `acquire_on_login` and `acquire_on_registration`): if one credential type is
required (`optional: false`) then that one takes precedence, i.e. is acquired first.

recovery.description: `recovery` determines whether users can start a recovery process, e.g. in case of a forgotten password.

enabled.description: `enabled` controls whether rate limiting is enabled or disabled.

store.description:
`store` sets the store for the rate limiter. When you have multiple instances of Hanko running, it is recommended to use
 the `redis` store because otherwise your instances each have their own states.

redis_config.description:
`redis_config` configures connection to a redis instance.
Required if `store` is set to `redis`

passcode_limits.description: `passcode_limits` controls rate limits for passcode operations.

password_limits.description: `password_limits` controls rate limits for password login operations.

token_limits.description: `token_limits` controls rate limits for token exchange operations.

tokens.description: `tokens` determines how many operations/requests can occur in the given `interval`.

interval.description:
`interval` determines when to reset the token interval.
It must be a (possibly signed) sequence of decimal
numbers, each with optional fraction and a unit suffix, such as "300ms", "-1.5h" or "2h45m".
Valid time units are "ns", "us" (or "µs"), "ms", "s", "m", "h".

address.description: `address` is the address of the redis instance in the form of `host[:port][/database]`.

password.description: `password` is the password for the redis instance.

display_name.description:
`display_name` is the service's name that some WebAuthn Authenticators will display to the user during registration
and authentication ceremonies.

id.description:
`id` is the [effective domain](https://html.spec.whatwg.org/multipage/browsers.html#concept-origin-effective-domain)
the passkey/WebAuthn credentials will be bound to.

origins.description:
`origins` is a list of origins for which passkeys/WebAuthn credentials will be accepted by the server. Must
include the protocol and can only be the effective domain, or a registrable domain suffix of the effective
domain, as specified in the [`id`](#id). Except for `localhost`, the protocol **must** always be `https` for
passkeys/WebAuthn to work. IP Addresses will not work.

For an Android application the origin must be the base64 url encoded SHA256 fingerprint of the signing
certificate.

RelyingParty.description: RelyingParty webauthn settings for your application using hanko.

SMTP.description: SMTP Server Settings for sending passcodes

keys.description:
`keys` are used to en- and decrypt the JWKs which get used to sign the JWTs issued by the API.
For every key a JWK is generated, encrypted with the key and persisted in the database.

You can use this list for key rotation: add a new key to the beginning of the list and the corresponding
JWK will then be used for signing JWTs. All tokens signed with the previous JWK(s) will still
be valid until they expire. Removing a key from the list does not remove the corresponding
database record. If you remove a key, you also have to remove the database record, otherwise
application startup will fail.

public.title: public
public.description: `public` contains the server configuration for the public API.

admin.title: admin
admin.description: `admin` contains the server configuration for the admin API.

address.description:
`address` is the address of the server to listen on in the form of host:port.

See [net.Dial](https://pkg.go.dev/net#Dial) for details of the address format.

name.description:
`name` determines the name of the service.
This value is used, e.g. in the subject header of outgoing emails.

audience.description:
`audience` is a list of strings that identifies the recipients that the JWT is intended for.
The audiences are placed in the `aud` claim of the JWT.
If not set, it defaults to the value of the`webauthn.relying_party.id` configuration parameter.

cookie.description: `cookie` contains configuration for the session cookie issued on successful registration or login.

enable_auth_token_header.description:
`enable_auth_token_header` determines whether a session token (JWT) is returned in an `X-Auth-Token`
header after a successful authentication. This option should be set to `true` if API and client applications
run on different domains.

issuer.description:
`issuer` is a string that identifies the principal (human user, an organization, or a service)
that issued the JWT. Its value is set in the `iss` claim of a JWT.

lifespan.description:
`lifespan` determines how long a session token (JWT) is valid. It must be a (possibly signed) sequence of decimal
numbers, each with optional fraction and a unit suffix, such as "300ms", "-1.5h" or "2h45m".
Valid time units are "ns", "us" (or "µs"), "ms", "s", "m", "h".

providers.title: providers
providers.description: `providers` contains the configurations for the available OAuth/OIDC identity providers.

redirect_url.description:
`redirect_url` is the URL the third party provider redirects to with an authorization code. Must consist of the base URL
of your running Hanko backend instance and the `callback` endpoint of the API,
i.e. `{YOUR_BACKEND_INSTANCE}/thirdparty/callback.`

Required if any of the [`providers`](#providers) are `enabled`.

error_redirect_url.description:
`error_redirect_url` is the URL the backend redirects to if an error occurs during third party sign-in.
Errors are provided as 'error' and 'error_description' query params in the redirect location URL.

When using the Hanko web components it should be the URL of the page that embeds the web component such that
errors can be processed properly by the web component.

You do not have to add this URL to the 'allowed_redirect_urls', it is automatically included when validating
redirect URLs.

Required if any of the [`providers`](#providers) are `enabled`. Must not have trailing slash.

default_redirect_url.description:
`default_redirect_url` is the URL the backend redirects to after it successfully verified
the response from any third party provider.

Must not have trailing slash.

allowed_redirect_urls.description:
`allowed_redirect_urls` is a list of URLs the backend is allowed to redirect to after third party sign-in was
successful.

Supports wildcard matching through globbing. e.g. `https://*.example.com` will allow `https://foo.example.com`
and `https://bar.example.com` to be accepted.

Globbing is also supported for paths, e.g. `https://foo.example.com/*` will match `https://foo.example.com/page1`
and `https://foo.example.com/page2`.

A double asterisk (`**`) acts as a "super"-wildcard/match-all.

See [here](https://pkg.go.dev/github.com/gobwas/glob#Compile) for more on globbing.

Must not be empty if any of the [`providers`](#providers) are `enabled`. URLs in the list must not have a trailing slash.

allow_linking.description:
`allow_linking` indicates whether existing accounts can be automatically linked with this provider.

Linking is based on matching one of the email addresses of an existing user account with the (primary)
email address of the third party provider account.

client_id.description:
`client_id` is the ID of the OAuth/OIDC client. Must be obtained from the provider.

Required if the provider is `enabled`.

enabled.description: `enabled` determines whether this provider is enabled.

secret.description:
`secret` is the client secret for the OAuth/OIDC client. Must be obtained from the provider.

Required if the provider is `enabled`.

apple.description: `apple` contains the provider configuration for Apple.

discord.description: `discord` contains the provider configuration for Discord.

github.description: `github` contains the provider configuration for GitHub.

google.description: `google` contains the provider configuration for Google.

linkedin.description: `linkedin` contains the provider configuration for LinkedIn.

microsoft.description: `microsoft` contains the provider configuration for Microsoft.

acquire_on_login.description:
`acquire_on_login` determines whether users, provided that they do not already have set a username,
	are prompted to provide a username on login.

acquire_on_registration.description: `acquire_on_registration` determines whether users are prompted to provide a username on registration.

enabled.description:
`enabled` determines whether users can set a unique username.

Usernames can contain letters (a-z,A-Z), numbers (0-9), and underscores.

max_length.description: `max_length` specifies the maximum allowed length of a username.

min_length.description: `min_length` specifies the minimum length of a username.

optional.description:
`optional` determines whether users must provide a username when prompted. The username can only be changed but
not deleted if usernames are required (`optional: false`).

use_as_login_identifier.description: `use_as_login_identifier` determines whether usernames, if enabled, can be used for logging in.

timeouts.title: timeouts
timeouts.description: `timeouts` specifies the timeouts for passkey/WebAuthn registration and login.

WebauthnSettings.description: WebauthnSettings defines the settings for the webauthn authentication mechanism

registration.description:
`registration` determines the time, in milliseconds, that the client is willing to wait for the credential
creation request to the WebAuthn API to complete.

login.description:
`login` determines the time, in milliseconds, that the client is willing to wait for the credential
 request to the WebAuthn API to complete.

callback.description: `callback` specifies the URL to which the change data will be sent.

meta:enum.email.send: Triggers on: an email was sent or should be sent
meta:enum.user: Triggers on: user creation, user deletion, user update, email creation, email deletion, change of primary email
meta:enum.user.update: Triggers on: user update, email creation, email deletion, change of primary email
meta:enum.user.update.email: Triggers on: email creation, email deletion, change of primary email
meta:enum.user.update.email.primary: Triggers on: change of primary email

events.title: events
events.description: `events` is a list of events this hook listens for.

allow_time_expiration.description:
`allow_time_expiration` determines whether webhooks are disabled when unused for 30 days
(only for database webhooks).

hooks.title: hooks
hooks.description:
`hooks` is a list of Webhook configurations.

When using environment variables the value for the `WEBHOOKS_HOOKS` key must be specified in the following
format:
`{"callback":"http://app.com/usercb","events":["user"]};{"callback":"http://app.com/emailcb","events":["email.send"]}`
